[36mOn the Bay[0;37m
     Gusty sea breezes force high foaming caps to form on the waves as they
dance on the water. As you pass through the mouth of the bay you observe
the high cliffs looking down from the edges of the shoreline, and a huge
pile of fallen rock to the north and west where the sea bashes violently in
a constant rhythm against the vast stone slabs. Back to the west the jagged
forms of the stone teeth marking the entrance to the bay stand defiantly
against the violence of the deep seas. Small strips of decaying weed float
atop the waters in places, at which the occasional fish can be seen
nibbling before once again disappearing into the waves.

[36mOn the Bay[0;37m

undulations, large white crests forming and dissolving into fragments of
foam as they collide with one another in their complex dance with the
tides. A white beach stretches along the edge of the eastern shoreline, on
the far side of the bay, while a jagged collection of rocks to the north
and west acts as a natural breakwater, the waves smashing against them
sending white plumes of spray high into the air.

[36mAt the Teeth of the Bay[0;37m
     Huge jagged shafts of dark rock rise up out of the sea in several
positions around the entrance to the bay, their weatherworn exteriors
sharpened and pitted by the elements. Waves crash loudly against the stone
in veritable explosions of water, filling the air with a fine mist. Beyond
these enormous guardians to the east a small bay beckons you to calmer
waters, the force of the wind and waves buffered somewhat by these massive
stone formations.

[36mIn Sight of Land[0;37m

land stretching along the eastern horizon, from where you can hear the
distant roar of the surf crashing against the shoreline. Birds circle high
in the sky, tiny specks in the distance, which wheel and dive toward the

the horizon in all other directions.

[36mTravelling the Sea Lanes[0;37m

direction at least, pushing you east.

[36mIn Sight of Land[0;37m
     The wide open waters of the Sirrion Sea give way to a faint line of
land stretching along the eastern horizon, from where you can hear the
distant roar of the surf crashing against the shoreline. Birds circle high
in the sky, tiny specks in the distance, which wheel and dive toward the
foaming crests in search of fish to dine upon. The waters stretch off into
the horizon in all other directions.

[36mPath to Castle Dread[0;37m
    This is a large but rocky path leading to Castle Dread into the
mountains. This whole place gives a lonely and uneasy feeling. The area is
inundated with the commoners and merchants of Nostar. To the west one can
see the harbor of Castle Dread, to the northeast to get a glimpse of Castle
Dread, secluded in the mountains and vales.

lies to the southwest from here.

[36mPath to Castle Dread[0;37m
    This is a large but rocky path leading to Castle Dread into the
mountains. This whole place gives a lonely and uneasy feeling. The area is
inundated with the commoners and merchants of Nostar. To the west one can
see the harbor of Castle Dread, to the northeast to get a glimpse of Castle
Dread, secluded in the mountains and vales.

[36mPath into the Mountains[0;37m
    This is a large road leading into the mountains. The surrounding area
is vertiginous and rocky, but the well-travelled road makes the trek much
easier. Close by, one can see the legendary vales, each oozing out languid
streams and waterways. One can already feel the spray created by the
streams, even though it is impossible to see the streams or the Nostar
river from this vantage.

[36mTop of the Rocky Path  [0;37m
    This peak stands at the top of the path, providing a clear view of the
surrounding areas, including Castle Dread itself. Castle Dread is located
directly to the east, it is separated from the surrounding area by a river
of small streams created by the nearby vales that serves as an impressive
watery moat. The spray is overwhelming and almost unbearable.

[36mAt the Edge of the Cliff[0;37m
    Here there is the edge of the cliff, a few hundred feet below, one can
see the river of languid streams and waterways. Castle Dread stands
ominously in the middle of the river on a giant support undoubtedly
reinforced by ancient magic. This is where the draw bridge is raised and
lowered across the perilous streams or the Nostar river that flows below.
Attached to the surrounding mountain sides are four gigantic chains
connecting to Castle Dread and serve as additional support. One of the
chain links is connected just north of here.

[36mThe Drawbridge[0;37m
    This is the huge draw bridge that connects Castle Dread to the rest of
world. The bridge is made of some strange adamantine material that can
withstand the oxidation from the immense spray, coming from below. The huge
drawbridge is the gates to the fortress city of Castle Dread, it is
connected to a huge mechanism that raises and lowers the drawbridge. When
the drawbridge is lifted, there would be no way to enter Castle Dread from
the ground.

    Waves from the Newsea crash onto the shoreline, sending spray of salty
water into the air. Strong gusts from the north whip at your clothes and
kick sand and water droplets into your face. From the eastern horizon to
the western horizon, all that can be seen are the waters of the Newsea.
Directly across the waters to the north you can barely make out a land mass
and a city, it must be Port o'Call. The sand along the shore becomes more
sparse to the south and a road leads away from the shoreline.
[33m[1mA large ferry braves rough waters of the Newsea.
A large wooden sign has been hammered into the ground here.
[0;37m[31m[1m<Myth> Fawe the Male Half Elf is standing here. (flying) (white aura)
<Myth> Captain Yimbo Slice is standing here. (flying) (white aura)
<Myth> Yim The Great is standing here. (flying) (white aura)
. . . emits an eerie glow.
<Myth> Yaza Daza, Mystical Light is standing here. (flying) (invisible) (white aura)
<Myth> Sir Yazzi Dragonbane is standing here. (flying) (invisible) (white aura)
A young resolute captain prepares his boat.

[36mRough Waters in the Newsea[0;37m
     You are on the rough waters of Newsea. The weather is harsh and the
sky is gloomy. It is very tough to navigate through the turbulent waters,
large waves and strong winds seem to cover much of this sea. The waters
here seems unnaturally dark, and you see few signs of sea life.

[36mThe Shores of Great Bay[0;37m
    The yellowish sands seamlessly slope into the waters of Newsea as the
waters ebb and flow along the shoreline. The sounds of the sea rhythmically
wash alongst the shore, offering a consistent melody. The caw of sea birds
can be heard before they are seen, taking off and landing atop the waters
to the west. The sandy beach leads eastwards and comes to a trailhead,
leading through some verdant rolling hills. The sky is partially cloudy,
and a drizzle of rain can be felt from time to time.

[36mA Trail to the Shore[0;37m
    The trail descends rapidly, the end of which can be seen leading to a
sandy shoreline. The waters of Newsea can be seen rushing onto the shore,
staining the sand with moisture. Far to the southeast, beyond the hills,
the terrain opens up into a vast desert known as the Plains of Dust. There
is almost a distinguishable line where the sands from the plains meets the
grass at the edge of the hills. The sun warms the hills, but some light
gray rain clouds can be seen moving in from the west.

[36mA Trail through the Hills[0;37m
    Far to the north, the green foothills give way to a massive wetlands
known as Sables Swamp. There is no visible path from here, and access to the
swamp must be granted from some other direction. Further still is the
southern edge of the Khalkists known as Onyx Teeth. Somewhere between the
two lies the ruins of Brukt, a long since destroyed ogre town. The green
hills continue all around, but a trail can be followed which runs east,
west, and south.

[36mA Well-Worn Trail in the Foothills[0;37m
    Warm, refreshing air blows in from the west, softly caressing your
skin. Lush green grass bends and swirls as if dancing in the sunlight as
the winds flow through. Verdant foothills gently rise and fall all around,
but a clearly marked trail cuts through them at the lowest point. Fresh
wagon tracks form a depression in the trail and can be traced to the east
and north. A lightly traveled trail runs further west.

[36mAn Intersection in the Foothills[0;37m
    A shady grove offers a cool place to rest at this intersection. The
rolling grasslands to the south extend beyond sight, running parallel to
the forest of Silvanesti. The southern tip of the Khalkist mountains lies a
great distance towards the west, and rise up like towering giants. Beyond
that, though not visible, lies the waters of New Sea. Ogre Peaks and Onyx
Teeth comprise the portion of the mountains to the west, and as the name
suggests, is home to many ogres. The land to the north is a mighty plain
known as Blode, where cities lie sprawled amidst the Khalkist mountains.
Skirting the northern tip of the Silvanesti forest, the road continues east
into the lands of Khur.

[36mBefore an Arid Desert[0;37m
    The cruel sun beats down on the road here, cracking the dried soil.
The land here suffers badly from the unrelenting winds that blow across the
desert to the west. Lizards take shelter in the shadows of the rocks where
the sand is not hot enough to roast them, but there is no shade large
enough for larger animals. Each step sinks into the searing sand, the air
thick and hazy, each breath like drowning in lava.

[36mCrossing the Thon-Thalas River[0;37m
    The beating sun bakes the dirt road in such heat that the road has
cracked into what almost resembles cobblestones. Insects scurry across,
careful not to stay in the heat for long, lest they become a permanent
melted fixture of the road. Shimmering waves of heat rise off of the road,
distorting your vision slightly. Far to the east, the lands of Khur lie
between here and the Balifor Bay, though all that can be seen is desert.
Somewhere located within is the City of Pashin, a hodgepodge city with both
Dwarven and Solamnic architecture. Often used as a stopping point for
caravans and trade wagons, Pashin is rumored to have one of the finest
bazaars in Ansalon. There is no shade in this stretch of road, and the only
option is to continue either north or south.

[36mApproaching the Hills of Khuri-Khan[0;37m
    Amidst the cool breezes and verdant expanse of grasses is this cool
road. Composed of mulch and dark black soil, the road curves east towards
the Khurman Sea and west towards the Khalkist mountains. This seems to be a
favored resting place of travelers, as there are several charred circles
near the path where the grass grows shorter. A large apple tree provides
shade over these campsites, as well as food and protection from the
elements. The cool breeze continues, undaunted, rolling in off of the waves
of the Khurman Sea, making you feel relaxed if but for a moment.

[36mCrossing the Thon-Thalas River[0;37m
    The beating sun bakes the dirt road in such heat that the road has
cracked into what almost resembles cobblestones. Insects scurry across,
careful not to stay in the heat for long, lest they become a permanent
melted fixture of the road. Shimmering waves of heat rise off of the road,
distorting your vision slightly. Far to the east, the lands of Khur lie
between here and the Balifor Bay, though all that can be seen is desert.
Somewhere located within is the City of Pashin, a hodgepodge city with both
Dwarven and Solamnic architecture. Often used as a stopping point for
caravans and trade wagons, Pashin is rumored to have one of the finest
bazaars in Ansalon. There is no shade in this stretch of road, and the only
option is to continue either north or south.

[36mBefore an Arid Desert[0;37m

The land here suffers badly from the unrelenting winds that blow across the
desert to the west. Lizards take shelter in the shadows of the rocks where
the sand is not hot enough to roast them, but there is no shade large
enough for larger animals. Each step sinks into the searing sand, the air
thick and hazy, each breath like drowning in lava.

thick and hazy, each breath like drowning in lava.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    There is almost no water to be found among the powdery sands, and no
trees whatsoever. A few cacti and tough low-lying bushes have managed to
stake out an existence, but little else. The ceaseless winds tear at the
sagebrush which has forced itself into the shallow soil, tearing at the
thin roots. Cruel winds wail as they fly violently over these godforsaken
plains.

[36mThe Ruins of Elial[0;37m
    The ruins of Elial rest here, endlessly battered and broken down by the
Plains of Dust. Elial was once the sister city of Purstal, but now both lie
crumbled and forgotten. A few small structures still remain intact, but
neglect will soon force them to collapse upon themselves. These ruins, much
like the others found in this wasteland, act as waypoints throughout the
region. Travelers might seek shelter in the ruins as they cross the plains,
which inadvertently attracts bandits and thieves. The ruins themselves can
be entered, but there is no indication of what lies hidden within.

[36mAmongst the Ruins of Elial[0;37m
    The road here leads west, further into the ruins of Elial. Once
spanning to other great trade cities such as Purstal, Qindaras, and
Wallach, the road is now buried beneath the sands and snow of the Plains of
Dust. The ruined city groans softly in the breeze, as many of the
surrounding structures have already crumbled in the distant past. Still,
the ruins may well make for good shelter from the harsh environment
beyond. Booted footprints can be seen in the rubble leading through the
streets to the west as somebody seems to have already set up camp.

[36mThe Center of the Ruins[0;37m
    Heaps of timber and stone have formed large piles of rubble all
throughout the ruins of Elial. Crumbling stone structures offer a scant
shelter from the winds and none from the sun when it is highest in the sky.

campfires litter the roads as though somebody has established themselves
here. Several buildings remain to the north but much of the debris has
cordoned off several areas of the once bustling trade city.

[36mThe Center of the Ruins[0;37m
    Heaps of timber and stone have formed large piles of rubble all
throughout the ruins of Elial. Crumbling stone structures offer a scant
shelter from the winds and none from the sun when it is highest in the sky.
Smaller buildings of rotten wood creak as the winds press on them and
threaten to topple them over. Despite the disarray, small tables and
campfires litter the roads as though somebody has established themselves
here. Several buildings remain to the north but much of the debris has
cordoned off several areas of the once bustling trade city.

[36mAmongst the Ruins of Elial[0;37m
    This cul-de-sac features three buildings that have fallen into
disrepair. Despite being unusable by most anyone's standards, it appears
someone has sought shelter inside. Faint flickers of light can be seen from
within, illuminating every cracked board and hole in their siding. Rubble

[36mAmongst the Ruins of Elial[0;37m
    This cul-de-sac features three buildings that have fallen into
disrepair. Despite being unusable by most anyone's standards, it appears
someone has sought shelter inside. Faint flickers of light can be seen from
within, illuminating every cracked board and hole in their siding. Rubble
has been cleared from their entrances and piled up along their sides. There
is no way around the buildings and the street only leads back towards the
center.

within, illuminating every cracked board and hole in their siding. Rubble

center.

[36mA Ramshackle Tavern[0;37m
    The rundown tavern has been abandoned for a long time, serving as just
another structure to provide a minimalistic shelter from the weather. The
remaining stores have long since been pilfered, and broken glass and bar
stools have cluttered the floors for ages. A random assortment of new

wood floor, making it sticky to walk on. The scent of body odor lingers
heavy in the air as if many unwashed persons were just here.

[36mThe Center of the Ruins[0;37m
    Heaps of timber and stone have formed large piles of rubble all
throughout the ruins of Elial. Crumbling stone structures offer a scant
shelter from the winds and none from the sun when it is highest in the sky.
Smaller buildings of rotten wood creak as the winds press on them and
threaten to topple them over. Despite the disarray, small tables and
campfires litter the roads as though somebody has established themselves
here. Several buildings remain to the north but much of the debris has
cordoned off several areas of the once bustling trade city.

[36mBefore a Huge Mound of Rubble[0;37m
    This seems to be the unofficial junk pile of Elial. All debris and
rubble from the streets must have been gathered here to form what little
passage there is within the ruined city. The heap of rubble contains
everything from bent and rusted old metal spoons to crumbling walls, and
forms a semicircle around the area. Beyond the debris lies the remains of
the city, but it seems even more unusable than what is left to the north,
which seems to be the only interesting portion of town.

[36mThe Center of the Ruins[0;37m
    Heaps of timber and stone have formed large piles of rubble all
throughout the ruins of Elial. Crumbling stone structures offer a scant
shelter from the winds and none from the sun when it is highest in the sky.
Smaller buildings of rotten wood creak as the winds press on them and
threaten to topple them over. Despite the disarray, small tables and
campfires litter the roads as though somebody has established themselves
here. Several buildings remain to the north but much of the debris has
cordoned off several areas of the once bustling trade city.

[36mA Roofless Building[0;37m
    This spacious room was likely the town hall due to its size and central
location. Most of the ceiling has crumbled and fallen here, creating large
piles of rubble. The exposed ceiling offers no protection from the sun, but
the walls have remained intact. A smaller room lies behind a door to the
west but there's no telling if it leads to anything important. Though the
room is littered with stone and dust, large clawed outlines can be seen on
the ground as though something too large to fit through the door had found
its way inside.

red dragon. Although Smolder is inexperienced in combat, he makes up for it
in ferocity and vigor. A large dragonrider's saddle is attached to his
scaly back, and wraps around his yellow stomach. His massive red wings are
tucked back alongside his torso, but judging by his size his wingspan is
easily thirty feet. Faint puffs of steam are released through the young
dragon's nostrils as he exhales, a reminder of his innate fire-breathing
ability.

[36mThe Center of the Ruins[0;37m
    Heaps of timber and stone have formed large piles of rubble all
throughout the ruins of Elial. Crumbling stone structures offer a scant
shelter from the winds and none from the sun when it is highest in the sky.
Smaller buildings of rotten wood creak as the winds press on them and
threaten to topple them over. Despite the disarray, small tables and
campfires litter the roads as though somebody has established themselves
here. Several buildings remain to the north but much of the debris has
cordoned off several areas of the once bustling trade city.

[36mThe Ruins of Elial[0;37m
    The ruins of Elial rest here, endlessly battered and broken down by the
Plains of Dust. Elial was once the sister city of Purstal, but now both lie
crumbled and forgotten. A few small structures still remain intact, but
neglect will soon force them to collapse upon themselves. These ruins, much
like the others found in this wasteland, act as waypoints throughout the
region. Travelers might seek shelter in the ruins as they cross the plains,
which inadvertently attracts bandits and thieves. The ruins themselves can
be entered, but there is no indication of what lies hidden within.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m

[36mA Choice of Paths[0;37m
    From this vantage point atop the small hill, you can see the top of
King's road extending far to the west for what seems like an eternity. The
road west is completely useless now, having been destroyed during the

the Plains of Dust. It is now a relic that serves as a harsh reminder that
even the mightiest can fall. A rocky trail from the north leads down the
hill, following King's Road at its base. An unfragmented section of the
road remains intact, and can be accessed from this point leading east into
the forests of Silvanesti, however that road is free of wagon tracks and
hoof prints, no doubt believing the tales of horrifying nightmares that
have befallen the once great nation.

[36mClimbing a Small Hill[0;37m
    King's Road extends up and down the hillside here, stretching on
seemingly forever. The path is not maintained and has not been for some
time. Piled stone walls built long ago segment the sides of the road,
creating a haphazard walkway up the hill. The plains extend all around,

valley, save for the unmaintained road system standing out from the sand.

[36mAlongside King's Road[0;37m
    The elevated highway that is King's road rises thirty feet beyond the
ground. Having been broken during the Cataclysm, the road is now a shell of
its former self. Aside from the roads state of disrepair, it sits too high
from the ground to be travelled on. Still, the ancient road serves as a
worthy guide through the harsh plains and towards the kingdom of
Silvanesti. To the west, the road has collapsed, leaving behind tall
pillars of stone that stretch out towards the sky and supporting nothing.

[36mAlongside King's Road[0;37m
    The elevated highway that is King's road rises thirty feet beyond the
ground. Having been broken during the Cataclysm, the road is now a shell of
its former self. Aside from the roads state of disrepair, it sits too high
from the ground to be travelled on. Still, the ancient road serves as a
worthy guide through the harsh plains and towards the kingdom of
Silvanesti. To the west, the road has collapsed, leaving behind tall
pillars of stone that stretch out towards the sky and supporting nothing.

    King's Road extends up and down the hillside here, stretching on
seemingly forever. The path is not maintained and has not been for some

creating a haphazard walkway up the hill. The plains extend all around,

valley, save for the unmaintained road system standing out from the sand.

[36mBeneath King's Road[0;37m
    King's Road was once a grand elevated highway which was supported
by large pillars thirty feet in the air running on pillars for 600 miles
from Thon-Thalas in the east to Purstal in the west. Originally molded from
stone by House Mason of the Silvanesti Elves as a means to travel from
Silvanesti, through the Plains of Dust and into Qualinesti, it was widely
used by merchants and travelers, however during the Cataclysm the highway
collapsed near Purstal and lies in ruins further west of that point.

[36mAlongside King's Road[0;37m
    King's Road runs parallel to the Khaldat river, too high and too
ruined to be used as a means of transport. Broken columns reach towards the
sky, a reminder of what was and what will never be, while the saffron
colored sands blow in invisible winds. The faint sound of scurrying can be
detected if one ignores the bubbling burble of the broad river stretching
east and south into the Plains of Dust. The sound is probably from the
small animals that call the desolation their home.

[36mThe Edge of King's Road[0;37m
    This once grand and beautifully crafted highway has been ravaged by the
harsh surrounding sands. It is said that King's Road once cut entirely
across what is now known as the Plains of Dust, leading all the way to
Sancrist. There is, however, little proof of King's Road extending beyond
this point, as anything that may lie further west is buried beneath the
sands. The road has collapsed, leaving heaps of rubble and debris on the
sands. King's road continues east, but is inaccessible from the ground.
Instead a much simpler road has been formed and runs alongside it's base.
[33m[1mA large shrub lies just off the main road.

[36mBefore the Ruins of Purstal[0;37m
    The road to the east lies covered in huge chunks of broken grey stone
that have been pushed to the edges to clear a path. The stones once belonged
to King's road, which still runs hundreds of miles east towards the
Thon-Thalas River, deep within the lands of Silvanesti. To the west is an
arched stone bridge, spanning a fork in the Torath River. A series of
peculiar lights flash briefly to the north, where the ruins of Purstal lay.
Once a major trading city, and part of the Kharolis Empire, nothing of
Purstal remains but broken gates and crumbled buildings.

[36mA Stone Bridge[0;37m
     The sky is gloomy and an occassional snowflake falls from the sky. The
bridge you stand on is made of solid spruce and loose dirt is packed in the
cracks to ensure that the many horses and caravans can travel effortlessly.
Below you, the River Torath gushes mightly with its blue colour reflecting
the high silt content of this glacially fed river. You shudder to imagine
trying to navigate this rapidly flowing stream and after seeing a large
chunk of ice drift by, you realize that to try to navigate on this river
would be impossible.

[36mA Trail in the Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Cool winds cut through your clothing, sending chills through your body
and adding insult to injury as they carry with them stinging grains of
reddish sand. This barren path cuts through the center of the Plains of
Dust, conjoining East Road and King's Road. Though not a road, the
semi-frozen ground and lack of vegetation makes for a more than adequate
trail. Laid with trailmarkers, the path through the plains is clear, though
merchants have been known to get disoriented and wander off during
particularly bad dust storms.

    Cool winds cut through your clothing, sending chills through your body

reddish sand. This barren path cuts through the center of the Plains of
Dust, conjoining East Road and King's Road. Though not a road, the
semi-frozen ground and lack of vegetation makes for a more than adequate
trail. Laid with trailmarkers, the path through the plains is clear, though
merchants have been known to get disoriented and wander off during
particularly bad dust storms.

[36mA Wooden Bridge[0;37m
     The sky is gloomy and an occassional snowflake falls from the sky. The
bridge you stand on is made of solid spruce and loose dirt is packed in the
cracks to ensure that the many horses and caravans can travel effortlessly.
Below you, the Twendle River gushes mightly with its blue colour reflecting
the high silt content of this glacially fed river. You shudder to imagine
trying to navigate this rapidly flowing stream and after seeing a large
chunk of ice drift by, you realize that to try to navigate on this river
would be difficult.

[36mThe Crumbling Remains of East Road[0;37m
    The smoke from the fires of the ruins of Twendle to the west create
rivulets of charcoal in the grey lifeless skies above the Plains of Dust.
The town's namesake river has cut a huge ravine into the chiffon sands of
the wastelands, dropping forty to fifty feet below the ground level as the
arctic waters rush ever southwards in a futile charge towards the Icewall
Glacier. Hills and burrows of ice and silica have begun to form in the
plains, like undulating waves of desolation.

[36mA Hilly Road Outside Twendle[0;37m
    Just south of the road lies a small village nestled deep within these
hills. The village looks mostly abandoned, and some of the stone huts have
become so badly damaged that they lie in ruins. Wisps of black smoke rise
from the remaining structures, but the village is a shell of its former
self. The inhabitants appear to be human, and although they are few they
seem well versed in the harsh winters they receive here. East Road
continues towards Tarsis to the west, but gives way to nothing but sand in
the east.

[36mAmidst the Ruins of Twendle[0;37m
    A once flourishing trading post, Twendle sat nestled amongst the soft
hills of East Road. Merchants from the surrounding region would often stop
and gather necessary supplies from the centrally located village. But as
the Cataclysm struck and devastated the region, Twendle no longer could
afford to stay open. The destruction of East Road meant that no trade would
come from the east, and soon the villagers packed up their belongings and
left. Most travelled west towards Tarsis, or left Southern Ansalon entirely.
A few stuctures still remain in the village, though they are inhabited
mostly by bandits or vagabonds.

passage to a settlement in the distance. Smoke trails emanating from the
sparse grouping of huts hint at the possibility of a village to the

travelers into a small trench leading up the valley.

[36mA Bend in the Road[0;37m

smooth by the years of element exposure. Although well traveled, the rocky

at your surroundings denotes the harsh conditions of the valley. The
winding path continues to the east and the south.

[36mA Cool Dry Road[0;37m
    This rocky, barren road twists northward and upward here. Scaling the
side of the valley, the twisty road gently leads out of the valley. Looking
west you can see a small town nestled within the dusty floor of the valley.
The air is dry and cold, the soil sandy and barren. Why anyone would build
a town in such a valley is inconceivable, aside from the fact that this is
a popular, well-traveled merchant route.

[36mA Scenic Road[0;37m
    Although the Plains of Dust are generally barren and frigid, this scenic
road offers a pleasant view of the surrounding valley. The hard-packed road
winds through the gradually sloping hills, which helps protect you from the
sharp, crisp breeze flowing in from the south. Lone pine trees and shrubs
dot the hillsides and struggle for survival in this barren wasteland. The
trees remind you of the tenacity of the barbarians and nomads that inhabit
much of the inhospitable region. The road continues through the valley to
the west, and rises gently as it cuts through the hills to the north.

[36mA Cool Dry Road[0;37m
    This rocky, barren road twists northward and upward here. Scaling the
side of the valley, the twisty road gently leads out of the valley. Looking
west you can see a small town nestled within the dusty floor of the valley.
The air is dry and cold, the soil sandy and barren. Why anyone would build
a town in such a valley is inconceivable, aside from the fact that this is
a popular, well-traveled merchant route.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    The desolate conditions of the Plains of Dust are not at all improved
by the advent whipping winds and biting sands. Nevertheless, a few tough
and sinewed bushes have managed to take root among the crags and cliffs of
this inhospitable environment. The sand driven by the winds forms an
ever-changing tapestry of hill and vale, shifting from hour to hour at the
whim of the invisible gusts. Smoke rises from a small camp to the north.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Icy cold waters rage along the deep ravine which cuts across the Plains
of Dust as strong and as deep as a dwarf's battleaxe. The desolate
conditions of the Plains of Dust are not at all improved by the advent of
the Twendle River: the waters are simply too far down the gulch to supply
any life-giving water to the plants above. Nevertheless, a few tough and
sinewed bushes have managed to take root among the crags and cliffs of this
inhospitable environment.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    The constant annual swings between unbearable heat and insufferable
chill have made even the most primitive of life avoid this godforsaken
tract of land. Nevertheless, tough, sinewy grasses and twiny underbrush
have managed to stake out an existence, despite the odds. Here and there
deep gorges have been carved by the paths of the buffeting gales, creating
dangerous canyons which threaten to swallow the plains at any moment.

[36mThe Crumbling Remains of East Road[0;37m
    The smoke from the fires of the ruins of Twendle to the west create
rivulets of charcoal in the grey lifeless skies above the Plains of Dust.
The town's namesake river has cut a huge ravine into the chiffon sands of
the wastelands, dropping forty to fifty feet below the ground level as the
arctic waters rush ever southwards in a futile charge towards the Icewall
Glacier. Hills and burrows of ice and silica have begun to form in the
plains, like undulating waves of desolation.

[36mA Wooden Bridge[0;37m
     The sky is gloomy and an occassional snowflake falls from the sky. The
bridge you stand on is made of solid spruce and loose dirt is packed in the
cracks to ensure that the many horses and caravans can travel effortlessly.
Below you, the Twendle River gushes mightly with its blue colour reflecting
the high silt content of this glacially fed river. You shudder to imagine
trying to navigate this rapidly flowing stream and after seeing a large
chunk of ice drift by, you realize that to try to navigate on this river
would be difficult.

[36mA Trail in the Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Cool winds cut through your clothing, sending chills through your body
and adding insult to injury as they carry with them stinging grains of
reddish sand. This barren path cuts through the center of the Plains of
Dust, conjoining East Road and King's Road. Though not a road, the
semi-frozen ground and lack of vegetation makes for a more than adequate
trail. Laid with trailmarkers, the path through the plains is clear, though
merchants have been known to get disoriented and wander off during
particularly bad dust storms.

[36mBefore the Ruins of Purstal[0;37m
    The road to the east lies covered in huge chunks of broken grey stone
that have been pushed to the edges to clear a path. The stones once belonged
to King's road, which still runs hundreds of miles east towards the
Thon-Thalas River, deep within the lands of Silvanesti. To the west is an
arched stone bridge, spanning a fork in the Torath River. A series of
peculiar lights flash briefly to the north, where the ruins of Purstal lay.
Once a major trading city, and part of the Kharolis Empire, nothing of
Purstal remains but broken gates and crumbled buildings.
[33m[1m[0;37m[31m[1m<Myth> Fawe the Male Half Elf is standing here. (flying) (white aura)

[36mThe Edge of King's Road[0;37m
    This once grand and beautifully crafted highway has been ravaged by the
harsh surrounding sands. It is said that King's Road once cut entirely
across what is now known as the Plains of Dust, leading all the way to
Sancrist. There is, however, little proof of King's Road extending beyond
this point, as anything that may lie further west is buried beneath the
sands. The road has collapsed, leaving heaps of rubble and debris on the
sands. King's road continues east, but is inaccessible from the ground.
Instead a much simpler road has been formed and runs alongside it's base.
[33m[1mA large shrub lies just off the main road.

[36mAlongside King's Road[0;37m
    King's Road runs parallel to the Khaldat river, too high and too
ruined to be used as a means of transport. Broken columns reach towards the
sky, a reminder of what was and what will never be, while the saffron
colored sands blow in invisible winds. The faint sound of scurrying can be
detected if one ignores the bubbling burble of the broad river stretching
east and south into the Plains of Dust. The sound is probably from the
small animals that call the desolation their home.

[36mAlongside King's Road[0;37m
    The elevated highway that is King's road rises thirty feet beyond the
ground. Having been broken during the Cataclysm, the road is now a shell of
its former self. Aside from the road's state of disrepair, it sits too high
from the ground to be travelled on. Still, the ancient road serves as a
worthy guide through the harsh plains and towards the kingdom of
Silvanesti. To the west, the road has collapsed, leaving behind tall
pillars of stone that stretch out towards the sky and supporting nothing.

[36mBefore the Ruins of Purstal[0;37m
    The road to the east lies covered in huge chunks of broken grey stone
that have been pushed to the edges to clear a path. The stones once belonged
to King's road, which still runs hundreds of miles east towards the
Thon-Thalas River, deep within the lands of Silvanesti. To the west is an
arched stone bridge, spanning a fork in the Torath River. A series of
peculiar lights flash briefly to the north, where the ruins of Purstal lay.
Once a major trading city, and part of the Kharolis Empire, nothing of
Purstal remains but broken gates and crumbled buildings.

[36mA Stone Bridge[0;37m
     The sky is gloomy and an occassional snowflake falls from the sky. The
bridge you stand on is made of solid spruce and loose dirt is packed in the
cracks to ensure that the many horses and caravans can travel effortlessly.
Below you, the River Torath gushes mightly with its blue colour reflecting
the high silt content of this glacially fed river. You shudder to imagine
trying to navigate this rapidly flowing stream and after seeing a large
chunk of ice drift by, you realize that to try to navigate on this river
would be impossible.
[33m[1mA pile of steel coins.

[36mA Trail in the Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Cool winds cut through your clothing, sending chills through your body
and adding insult to injury as they carry with them stinging grains of
reddish sand. This barren path cuts through the center of the Plains of
Dust, conjoining East Road and King's Road. Though not a road, the
semi-frozen ground and lack of vegetation makes for a more than adequate
trail. Laid with trailmarkers, the path through the plains is clear, though
merchants have been known to get disoriented and wander off during
particularly bad dust storms.
[33m[1mA wooden trailmarker points towards the west and east.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Sagebrush wanders erratically among scrawny pines and low-lying bushes
in this part of the Plains of Dust, driven ceaselessly by the winds that
howl along the god-forsaken lands like the plaintive cry of a starved wolf.
The roar of the Twendle River adds to the din, creating a cacophony of
noise, making shouting a necessity for even the most basic communication.
The deep canyon carved by the river only amplifies the ruckus.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Cold winds blow across the Plains of Dust, driven from the icy tundra
along the Icewall Glacier, with a fury unbroken by tree or cliff. The sand
driven by the winds forms an ever-changing tapestry of hill and vale,
shifting from hour to hour at the whim of the invisible gusts. Despite the
chill air it seems almost unconscionably hot as well, for there is no shade
in this godforsaken wasteland.

[36mThe Murder Mounds[0;37m

northern path leading back to its source, the Torath River. The Plains of
Dust are particularly inhospitable here: a few scraggly bits of brush have
braved the dry earth and pitiless winds, but besides that no life is
visible. Everywhere is rock and dust, the dismal landscape broken only by
the occasional jagged cliff face and the ever present canyon the Shin has
carved in its fruitless path towards the Icewall Glacier.

[36mThe End of River Shin[0;37m
    Icewall Glacier dominates the horizon to the south as the steep canyon
walls gradually give way to the wide flat expanse of the Plains of Dust and
the flow from the River Shin dwindles to a trickle. The waters themselves
either disperse into the plains or are drawn down into an underground flow.
The spreading water has formed a small icy marsh which is overgrown with
cold-tolerant bushes, grasses, and lichens. Small, standing pools of water
are frozen over by the cold temperatures.
[33m[1mThe river has slowed to a trickle as it empties into the surrounding plains.

[36mA Ledge Overlooking the Plains[0;37m
    The cliff ledge extends from the face of the mountain just a short
ways, but provides an excellent vantage point which faces to the south. The
vertical cliff face rises even higher above, but is smoothed through
attrition by the ever-present winds and is unscaleable. This ledge provides
a clear view of the Plains of Dust as it stretches southward towards the
mighty Icewall.

[36mThe Murder Mounds[0;37m
    The River Shin comes to and end westwards here, breaking from the
northern path leading back to its source, the Torath River. The steep
rolling foothills are particularly inhospitable here: a few scraggly bits
of brush have braved the dry earth and pitiless winds, but besides that no
life is visible. Everywhere is rock and dust, the dismal landscape broken
only by the occasional jagged cliff face and the ever present canyon the
Shin has carved in its fruitless path towards the Icewall Glacier.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m

marengo powder by the harsh winds that blow along the Plains with gale
force, clog the eyes and make breathing difficult. A few tough plants have

brightness.

pink in the unfiltered light of this barren wasteland.

[36mThe Scorpion Wadi[0;37m
    The deep crevasse is known by the local inhabitants as the Scorpion
Wadi. The dried river bed curves like the tail of a scorpion and is also
home to many of the small black creatures. Small caves and canyons are
spread throughout the area, making it extremely easy to hide or defend from
enemies. Dark grasses with thick stalks grow along the edges of the
crevasse, creating a strange, shaggy shade which extends deep into the dry
earth.

[36mThe Mouth of a Canyon[0;37m
    The dry ground has turned from sand and silt to hard-packed clay and
rock. A wide trail slopes downward as it descends into a deep canyon. Caves
and overhangs have formed in the sandstone cliff faces, which were once the
shores of a since dried river. The canyon deepens and curves behind a wall
of rock, and the canyon walls only grow higher. Unable to see into the
caves that have been weathered into the rock, this canyon entrance makes
for the perfect place to be ambushed.

[36mThe Beginning of a Winding Canyon[0;37m
    Strange pawprints and insect tracks can be seen in the sediment which
has dried and settled here. The canyon walls are high above and are riddled
with openings and caves that may or may not lead further in. Rocks and
boulders both large and small have accumulated as the dry walls crack and
crumble, leaving ample hiding places for creatures of all sorts. The canyon
curves around with little reference as to how long it extends.

[36mA Curve in the Canyon[0;37m
    The canyon snakes along the dried earth to the north and west, but
beyond that is unclear. A ledge above is almost indistinguishable but seems
to follow the same curvature as the canyon bottom. It would be easy for
someone up above to stalk a hapless wanderer should they so wish, and it
would be nearly impossible for someone at the bottom to see them. The sound
of skittering rocks are amplified by the walls of the canyon as they slide
down the cliffs, and what caused them to fall is unknown.

[36mThe Bottom of a Dry Canyon[0;37m
    The bottom of the canyon here seems to be at its widest point, but
countless monochrome boulders disguise the surface of the cliff face. Some
large holes have been burrowed into the canyon walls, large enough for a
mountain lion to hide within. The dryness of the land makes a perfect
breeding ground for scorpions of which there are plenty. Most are too small
and inconsequential, but a cautionless step could warrant a poisonous
sting. What at first glance looked like a rock tumbling from the cliff
ledge was actually a much larger scorpion curled up as it fell. Not even
the insects are safe from the precariousness of the rocks here.

[36mAn Undercut Cave in the Canyon[0;37m
    Disguised by the monotonous geology of the canyon, this undercut in the
cave is tough to discern from outside. The canyon wall provides shelter
from the blaring sun which beats down mercilessly upon these rocks. The
shade here has significantly reduced the temperature which is much higher
to the west as the winds of the surrounding plains are unable to find their
way to the bottom of the canyon. Bits of trash and unnatural scraps signify
the presence of squatters, campers, or outlaws that call these canyons
home.

[36mThe Bottom of a Dry Canyon[0;37m
    The bottom of the canyon here seems to be at its widest point, but
countless monochrome boulders disguise the surface of the cliff face. Some
large holes have been burrowed into the canyon walls, large enough for a
mountain lion to hide within. The dryness of the land makes a perfect
breeding ground for scorpions of which there are plenty. Most are too small
and inconsequential, but a cautionless step could warrant a poisonous
sting. What at first glance looked like a rock tumbling from the cliff
ledge was actually a much larger scorpion curled up as it fell. Not even
the insects are safe from the precariousness of the rocks here.

[36mA Curve in the Canyon[0;37m
    The canyon snakes along the dried earth to the north and west, but
beyond that is unclear. A ledge above is almost indistinguishable but seems
to follow the same curvature as the canyon bottom. It would be easy for
someone up above to stalk a hapless wanderer should they so wish, and it
would be nearly impossible for someone at the bottom to see them. The sound
of skittering rocks are amplified by the walls of the canyon as they slide
down the cliffs, and what caused them to fall is unknown.

[36mThe Beginning of a Winding Canyon[0;37m
    Strange pawprints and insect tracks can be seen in the sediment which
has dried and settled here. The canyon walls are high above and are riddled
with openings and caves that may or may not lead further in. Rocks and
boulders both large and small have accumulated as the dry walls crack and
crumble, leaving ample hiding places for creatures of all sorts. The canyon
curves around with little reference as to how long it extends.

[36mThe Mouth of a Canyon[0;37m
    The dry ground has turned from sand and silt to hard-packed clay and
rock. A wide trail slopes downward as it descends into a deep canyon. Caves
and overhangs have formed in the sandstone cliff faces, which were once the
shores of a since dried river. The canyon deepens and curves behind a wall
of rock, and the canyon walls only grow higher. Unable to see into the
caves that have been weathered into the rock, this canyon entrance makes
for the perfect place to be ambushed.

[36mThe Scorpion Wadi[0;37m
    The deep crevasse is known by the local inhabitants as the Scorpion
Wadi. The dried river bed curves like the tail of a scorpion and is also
home to many of the small black creatures. Small caves and canyons are
spread throughout the area, making it extremely easy to hide or defend from
enemies. Dark grasses with thick stalks grow along the edges of the
crevasse, creating a strange, shaggy shade which extends deep into the dry
earth.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Parched, dry dunes rise throughout the desert around you, shaped by the
warm winds. The sandy hills gleam red and pink in the unfiltered light of
this barren wasteland. A few tough plants have managed to forge a life
among the buffeting gales and the bruising brightness, but their dried
leaves and wiry underbrush offer little more than shade for the insects.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Sagebrush wanders erratically among scrawny pines and low-lying bushes
in this part of the Plains of Dust, driven ceaselessly by the winds that
howl along the god-forsaken lands like the plaintive cry of a starved wolf.
The whistle of the whipping winds adds to the din, creating a cacophony of
noise, making shouting a necessity for even the most basic communication.
The deep canyons only amplify the ruckus.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Scattered smaller rocks lie around massive boulders, breaking up the
monotony of the dead lands. What little life that has found a way to
survive in the harsh environment is constantly vexed by the sun and
incessant winds. Massive waves of yellow-grey sands roll into hillocks and
shallow valleys in this part of the Plains of Dust.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m

the raging torrent of water, leaving nothing at the end except mud and the

bushes have sprung up, thirstily drinking up the last remnants of the
Newsea's outlet, providing a sustenance sufficient enough to battle the
frigid winds which blow from Icewall Glacier, barely visible far to the
south.

cold-tolerant bushes, grasses, and lichens. Small, standing pools of water
are frozen over by the cold temperatures.

[36mThe River Shin[0;37m
    The plain north-to-south flow of the river is only slightly interrupted
by a bizarre visual. In the middle of the river lie the shattered remnants
of a small stone building. The river bends slightly at the point,
indicating that, most likely, erosion of the canyon wall eventually became
severe enough to pull down a structure that had previously been atop it.
Years of flow have pushed the stones away from the eastern bank and into
the middle of the river. A crumbling chimney protrudes from the surface of
the water and is covered over with ice and lichens.

[36mThe Frigid Plains of Dust[0;37m
    The bitter cold winds blow across the Plains of Dust, cast from the
mighty Icewall that lies to the south. The wind howls as it carries with it
a light powdering of snow which settles on the ground briefly before
melting. The landscape is frozen in time and as unyielding as the compact
earth beneath your feet. Weathered shrubs have found a way to cling to
life, growing mere inches as the years drag on, but they only seem to
confirm the sparsity of the land. The chilling winds rise and fall with
immeasurable precision, yet they never seem to cease.

the Plains of Dust, has now shrunken to little more than a damp patch of
ground. A weak creek fades into the saffron colored sands, and thirsty
plants pull every available ounce of moisture from the petering course. The
deep canyon of the Gnome Gulch is visible to the north, but the ruins of
the Old Coast Road dominate this area. While this part of the road is only
used in winter, a careful examination reveals the footprints of icefolk in
the dust.

[36mAt the Bottom of Gnome Gulch[0;37m
    The Twendle River has emerged from the Gnome Gulch, its weakening flow
now more akin to stream than river. A shallow rampart is all that separates
the dying waters from the Plains of Dust, and a surprising amount of plant
life has grown in the barren topsoil, despite the multitude of rocks,
boulders, and crags which scar the surface. A few stalwart pines have dared
to reach towards the unforgiving sky, while hearty brush and bushes grow
thick along the damp banks.

[36mAt the Bottom of Gnome Gulch[0;37m
    There is no cold like the cold of the Twendle River. Housed in darkness
formed by massive cliffs which line either side of the rushing waters, the
river runs ragged towards the towering crystallized limestone of Icewall
Glacier. The winds, trapped by the faceless canyon walls, run faster than
the river, deafening the ears with their incessant roar. Yet perhaps the
greatest chill in this freezing environment is the chill from the soul of
one who sees such a bleak and lifeless world, formed by the arrogance of
man, destroying life and leaving only this frigid, dead shell.

[36mThe Twendle River[0;37m
    Even in the harsh environment of the Plains of Dust, along the steep

the torrent has allowed life to teem in the shadowy light which battles
along the edge of the crevasse. A few fruit-bearing shrubs have cropped up
along one edge of the cliff face, while lizards and tiny skinks scramble
between the exposed rocks.

[36mThe Twendle River[0;37m
    This is the bottom of a deep, dark chasm. Forty feet above, the pale
rays of light which lambast the Plains of Dust can be seen, but none of
that light ever reaches this deep into the crevasse: the walls are too
steep, the crack is too narrow. A raging river rushes along the bottom of
this ravine, flowing with an intensity which is doomed to fade, making a
desperate escape from the New Sea to the craggy limestone of Icewall
Glacier. Like everything in the Plains, this river is fated to fail, but
its furious onslaught in the face of failure is still a sight to behold.

[36mThe Twendle River[0;37m

but to no avail. Steep cliffs line either side of the river, almost

jut from the steep exposures of sandstone, a few clumps of sagebrush have
managed to tenaciously cling and find purchase.

[36mA Fork in the River[0;37m
    The River Torath flows from the east here, and splits its flow into a
smaller stream that breaks off from the primary flow and turns south, and a
larger stream which continues in an easterly direction. At the junction
between the disparate flows, a collection of massive boulders juts from the
ground to part the waters. These boulders are home to a large family of
birds, as several nests have been established among them. Presumably the
birds live here to feast on the fish that thrive in the eddying waters at
the river's junction.
[33m[1mThe river crashes against the canyon walls as it splits direction.

[36mA Fork in the River[0;37m
    The River Torath flows from the east here, and splits its flow into a
smaller stream that breaks off from the primary flow and turns south, and a
larger stream which continues in an easterly direction. At the junction
between the disparate flows, a collection of massive boulders juts from the
ground to part the waters. These boulders are home to a large family of
birds, as several nests have been established among them. Presumably the
birds live here to feast on the fish that thrive in the eddying waters at
the river's junction.

[36mThe River Torath[0;37m
    Tall cliffs of craggy rock rise high above the surface of the river
that has cut its way across the surface of this stretch of the Plains of
Dust. A brisk chill hangs in the air, and its evidence is apparent in all
the perpetual ice that clings to small outcroppings along the sides of the
gully and the frost that decorates rocks that break the surface of the
river. The river itself is especially treacherous here, between the cold
muddy banks and near complete lack of handholds as it flows from east to
west.
[33m[1mThe river flows strongly here, depositing ice and sediment along its steep banks.
[0;37m[31m[1m<Myth> Fawe the Male Half Elf is standing here. (flying) (white aura)

A flightless feral seriemas wades along the icy riverbank, looking for fish.

[36mThe River Torath[0;37m
    The cliffs to the north are home to a small grove of trees that are
growing on a near vertical surface. An assortment of both evergreens and
broadleaf trees gives the impression of clinging precariously to tiny
outcroppings of rocks, while the reality is that their roots burrow deep
into the ground much as any other tree. A short rope has been tied to the
branch of one of them, and it dangles down perhaps a dozen feet. The
southern cliffs are also home to plant life, but theirs is simple scrub
brush accented by the occasional tall grass. The river flows in from the
east and continues to the west.
[33m[1mThe river flows strongly here, depositing ice and sediment along its steep banks.

[36mA Fork in the River[0;37m
    Torpid water struggles on its westward and southward journey at the
base of a steep canyon fork, which presumably cracks the surface of the
Plains of Dust high above. The southbound waters continue toward the
Icewall Glacier while the westbound waters will flow into the Blood Sands.
While perhaps only a trick of the odd angles of light deep in the canyon,
the river flowing west appears to shimmer with a faint red hue, perhaps
caused by clay and silt from the Blood Sands. Tall walls of rock tower to
the north, with boulders threatening to topple at any moment from more than
thirty feet above.
[33m[1mThe river crashes against the canyon walls as it splits direction.

[36mRed Rose River[0;37m
    So named due to a red hue caused by mud and sediment from the Blood
Sands, the Red Rose River flows east to west. It cuts through rocky ground
forming cliffs that are about twenty feet high. Large boulders are visible
in the cliff sides, and apparently have, on occasion, fallen from the
cliffs to land in the water. A small length of white water has formed here
because of the toppled stones, and eddying pools are present on both the
north and south sides of the river above the rapids. To the west the cliffs
appear to lessen in height, and this gives the odd visual illusion of the
river flowing uphill.
[33m[1mThe river flows strongly here, depositing ice and sediment along its steep banks.

[36mRed Rose River[0;37m
    The Red Rose River ends here in a small pool of churning water. Small
trickles of water can be seen moving off in every direction, but they
quickly disappear into the rocky ground, either due to evaporation into the
dry air, or due to flowing down into invisible subterranean passages. The
high cliffs that extend along the riverbanks to the east end gradually here
at the pool, dropping in height from about ten feet on the eastern edge of
the pool to only a foot or two along the majority of the western edge. The
dirt and mud along the banks is a deep ruddy red. The water in the pool at
the far side is only a couple of feet deep, an inglorious final destination
for the seemingly impossible flow of seawater away from the ocean and into
the Plains of Dust.
[33m[1mThe river flows strongly here, depositing ice and sediment along its steep banks.

[36mBefore the Red Rose River[0;37m
    All that remains of the muddy red river is a trickle which quickly
dries up in the warmth of the plains. A very shallow pool of water has
formed just to the east, and though the murky waters are impenetrable by
light, it can't be very deep. The lands slope as they continue to the east,
forming small cliffs and ledges to the north and south. The thin riverbanks
on either side do not support much life as they are just as dry and
neglected as the rest of the Plains of Dust. The ground rises into sandy
hills to the west, which aside from the river is the only way to travel.
[33m[1mThe river has slowed to a trickle as it empties into the surrounding plains.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    The sandy hills gleam red and pink in the unfiltered light of this
barren wasteland, while thorny primrose grows in long vines and stems along
the high banks of the deep ravine which houses the unnaturally shaded
flume. Forgotten huts and a few scraggly plants have dared to break the
incessant monotony of flat land and undulating plain. To the east, the Red
Rose River slows to a trickle in the sandy wastelands.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    These are the sands that time forgot. During the Age of Mortals, the
land has steadily gone from dry to even more desert-like. The summer months
seem to stretch out longer into spring and autumn, while the winter is
cruel and cold. The constant annual swings between unbearable heat and
insufferable chill have made even the most primitive of life avoid this
godforsaken tract of land. Nevertheless, tough, sinewy grasses and twiny
underbrush have managed to stake out an existence, despite the odds.

[36mThe Ruins of Wallach[0;37m
    The former city of Wallach now lies in ruins, toppled by a rare
earthquake and covered by the reddish sands that form this part of the
Plains of Dust. The only structure that isn't completely destroyed is a
temple of Zivilyn that has been mostly swallowed by the sands. Once a
prosperous town with emphasis on worshipping the god of wisdom, the
crumbled town has not had any residents for many centuries. A towering
vallenwood tree can be seen in the near distance to the northeast and is
likely the reason the town of Wallach was erected here in the first place.

plain.

[36mThe Run[0;37m

[36mThe Run[0;37m
    The earth groans as the shallow ash-like sands of the Plains of Dust
blow through The Run, driven by a wind which knows no master, nor reprieve.
Small whirlwinds of white-grey silica spin in futility along the relative
flat of the land: while there is a faint rise and fall from the
ever-shifting dunes and dales they rarely get above ten feet high and do
nothing to break the apathetic stretch of horizon visible in all direction.

[36mThe Run[0;37m
    Coral as sharp as a razor lies scattered between the puce soil and the
occasional gunmetal rock which has broken through the cinereous ground. A
thousand years ago this was the bottom of the ocean, and life teemed along
the sandy surface and in the salty waters above. Now, all of that is gone,
disappeared in a haze of human hubris. What is left is the pathetic shade
of grey and white stretching out into oblivion in all direction.

[36mThe Run[0;37m
    The dirt in this part of The Run is quite shallow, revealing large
pieces of sun-bleached coral and charcoal-grey rocks just a few inches
beneath the surface. The winds which whip along the plains drive the soil
into small piles, revealing the hard remnants of oceanic life below, now
nothing more than the dirge of ages past. The Run has become little more
than a desert of ash, making life arduous and death unavoidable.

    These are the sands that time forgot. During the Age of Mortals, the

seem to stretch out longer into spring and autumn, while the winter is

underbrush have managed to stake out an existence, despite the odds.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    With the lights out, the desert is littered loosely with black spots of

like a pipe organ. Eldritch wails sing songs of loss, driven by relentless
wind carrying sand that exfoliates the skin and stings the eye. Dry grasses
whip in the gale, drumming as they strike the ground, creating a cacophony
which is almost deafening.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    In the stillness above the Plains of Dust, two hawks break the silence
with menacing caws. They quarrel with a viciousness brought on by immense
hunger. The otherwise lifeless sky stretches across the vast plains, as if
the two were part of their own bleak and endless world. Scattered amongst
massive boulders are smaller rocks, which serve only to break up the
monotony of the dead lands. What little life that has found a way to
survive in the harsh environment is constantly vexed by the sun and
incessant winds.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    The constant annual swings between unbearable heat and insufferable

tract of land. Nevertheless, tough, sinewy grasses and twiny underbrush
have managed to stake out an existence, despite the odds. Here and there
deep gorges have been carved by the paths of the buffeting gales, creating
dangerous canyons which threaten to swallow the plains at any moment.

[36mThe Road to Tarsis[0;37m
    This, the road to Tarsis, strides boldly through the Plains of Dust,
plunging eastward through the plains and west towards the exotic city of
Tarsis. Glacial winds gust in from the south, hampering your journey. The
plains respond to these forceful winds, born in the heart of Icewall, with
incredible dust storms that constantly threaten to encroach upon Tarsis and
the roads leading to her. Very few plants have the will or tenacity to try
growing on these rocky soils, and the slightest green of a stubborn moss is
a sight for sore eyes.

wayward land.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Sagebrush wanders erratically among scrawny pines and low-lying bushes
in this part of the Plains of Dust, driven ceaselessly by the winds that
howl along the god-forsaken lands like the plaintive cry of a starved wolf.
The whistle of the whipping winds adds to the din, creating a cacophony of
noise, making shouting a necessity for even the most basic communication.
The deep canyons only amplify the ruckus.

[36mWithin a Small Cave[0;37m
    The cave has been carved into the side of the rocky outcrop and offers
excellent shelter from outside. Not only is the cave protected from the
harsh terrain, it is completely hidden from view. There are dozens of these
caverns scattered throughout the canyons and rock formations in the Plains
of Dust, but most go unnoticed. The cave is far enough from the road to
make it unlikely that it is used by bandits. Instead, the cave serves as
protection should the weather turn while traveling between Rigitt and
Tarsis.

[36mThe Plains of Dust[0;37m
    Cold, bitter winds wrack the pewtered sands which cover the forgotten
landscape of the Plains of Dust. The winds blow tiny granules of silica
against the cracked and pitted crags and canyons. The soil is almost
completely bereft of life, although a few tufts of sagebrush manage to find
root along the edge of the trails.

[36mA Bend in the Road[0;37m
    The East Road curves along a ridge through the southern reaches of the
Plains of Dust. A shallow crevasse has formed in the earth to the north,
but prevents passage nonetheless. The road continues eastward where it can
be seen curving once again to the north. A short distance to the west it
slopes downwards and is covered by rocks large enough to prevent passage.
Far beyond that, the northern edge of Ice Mountain Bay can be seen. A small
fishing village is recognizable as the village of Rigitt, which lies
further south.

[36mThe Road to Rigitt[0;37m
    The road runs directly south into the village of Rigitt, but continues
out of sight to the north. The Plains of Dust extend to the east,
encircling the village and extending beyond. Although the Plains of Dust
are famous for their red-hued sand, the ground is mostly frozen from the
cold and looks to be more gray than anything else. The biting winds can be
felt as they skip across the waters of Ice Mountain Bay to the west.

[36mAn Old Coast Road[0;37m
    To the south lies the village of Rigitt, its friendly atmosphere a
stark contrast to the bleakness of the Plains of Dust which lie to the
north. Harsh winds kick up pelting grains of sand which sting the skin. An
intense heat begins to beat down upon the road, causing a distorted and
wavering visage of the road that leads northward. Meanwhile, the town to
the south seems to offer refuge with its protective walls and proximity to
the water.

[36mThe Northern Entrance of Rigitt[0;37m
    The northern entrance to the town of Rigitt lies open and unguarded.
There is no gate to prevent outsiders from wandering freely into the city,
and there is little need. The town makes its living as a shipping and
trading town, but has no real wealth to speak of. The primary source of
trade comes from New Tarsis, but a rapidly expanded shipping industry will
one day dominate the cities source of revenue. A road leads south towards
the center of the city while to the west is a tall lighthouse that towers
of the waters of Ice Mountain Bay.

recently laid with yellowish cobblestones. The stones themselves are a

abundance in the region.

[36mThe Intersection of Barnacle Boulevard and Starfish Street[0;37m
    The yellow cobblestone streets of Barnacle Boulevard are intersected at
this junction by a hard-packed dirt road. Starfish Street, which runs east
to west, is not as large as the former, but well worn wagon tracks seem to
indicate that it sees its fair share of use. The massive bay called Ice
Mountain Bay lies nearly a hundred yards to the west, while some small and
new looking structures comprise the town to the east and south.

have been left to remain just west of here and act as a sort of barrier to

towards the center of town.

[36mFrancesca's Fish Market[0;37m
    An assortment of freshly caught and gutted fish display on long tables
covered in crushed ice. The ice beds keep the wooden shack's air extremely
frigid and moist, which stands in stark contrast to the warm, arid climate
of the village. Although hundreds of raw fish are exposed to the air here,
the scent of raw fish is virtually nonexistent, further testifying to the
trader's expert care and freshness of the catch.

the distance.

[36mAn Old Coast Road[0;37m
    To the south lies the village of Rigitt, its friendly atmosphere a
stark contrast to the bleakness of the Plains of Dust which lie to the
north. Harsh winds kick up pelting grains of sand which sting the skin. An
intense heat begins to beat down upon the road, causing a distorted and
wavering visage of the road that leads northward. Meanwhile, the town to
the south seems to offer refuge with its protective walls and proximity to
the water.

[36mThe Road to Rigitt[0;37m
    The road runs directly south into the village of Rigitt, but continues
out of sight to the north. The Plains of Dust extend to the east,
encircling the village and extending beyond. Although the Plains of Dust
are famous for their red-hued sand, the ground is mostly frozen from the
cold and looks to be more gray than anything else. The biting winds can be
felt as they skip across the waters of Ice Mountain Bay to the west.

[36mA Muddy Street Through Zeeriak[0;37m
    Trudging past the drafty shacks, you are beginning to feel the
desperation that seems to infect the residents of this shabby village. Just
as you turn to make your way back to your warm lodgings, you notice a
building to the north that is conspicuous because of its unbroken walls.
You can see stacks of boxes against the building to the north. Perhaps there
is more than meets the eye to this village after all.

[36mA Small House[0;37m
    The inside of this decrepit shack is even more depressing than the
outside.  A bone chilling draft blows in through unshuttered windows and the
many spaces in the walls where planks have been torn out for use as firewood.
Despair creeps into your mind at the thought of living in such conditions,
and you are glad for the warmth of the fire in the inn.

[36mThe Commons of Zeeriak[0;37m
    The common area of Zeeriak is a dismal place.  Few residents tarry in
the mud and slush for too long.  A narrow path of wooden planks leads to the
east where a run-down tavern can be seen.  To the west, the freshly painted
facade of the Wooly Tusker Inn beckons invitingly.  Shabby houses dot the
rutted track leading north, and to the south, a larger path leading away from
the village can be made out.

[36mOn Old Coast Road[0;37m
    The air bites at the skin with its frigid sting as the ever-present
winds blow in from the Icewall Glacier to the south. Despite the
inhospitable climate and terrain, the area sparkles with a majestic glow as
the sun is reflected from the snow and ice. Old Coast Road continues far to
the north, where the air is slightly warmer. A small settlement can be seen
to the east, coated in a powdering of snow.

[36mA Hidden Warehouse[0;37m
    Large crates and barrels fill a good portion of this room.  Some bearing
the mark of a merchant from Tarsis or Balifor.  Yet others are covered in
symbols unrecognizable to you.  Perhaps they come from the far south, where
it is said a strange race of insect-men live.  Whatever the source, you are
certain the original owners never intended for this merchandise to find its
way here.

[36mThe Commons of Zeeriak[0;37m
    The common area of Zeeriak is a dismal place.  Few residents tarry in
the mud and slush for too long.  A narrow path of wooden planks leads to the
east where a run-down tavern can be seen.  To the west, the freshly painted
facade of the Wooly Tusker Inn beckons invitingly.  Shabby houses dot the
rutted track leading north, and to the south, a larger path leading away from
the village can be made out.

[36mOn Old Coast Road[0;37m

inhospitable climate and terrain, the area sparkles with a majestic glow as

the north, where the air is slightly warmer. A small settlement can be seen
to the east, coated in a powdering of snow.

[36mOn Old Coast Road[0;37m
    Softened by a light powdering of snow, the Old Coast Road here travels
south towards a partition of the Icewall Glacier. Rocky crags offer some
respite from the unrelenting gale, as the massive rift of the Icewall tears
across the horizon like the frozen blade of a forgotten sword. The powdered
scintilla in the air rest briefly on the ground before being forced aloft
again by the sempiternal winds, providing little topsoil to nurture the
scattered brush which clings tenuously to life.

[36mOn Old Coast Road[0;37m
    Freezing winds blow in from the south, blasting across the
countryside unbounded by building or tree. The ecru terrain has been
bleached by the constant powdering of light snow which blows off the
Icewall Glacier far to the south. Even in the dimmest illumination the
glare of the massive icy rift creates wild patterns of light and dark.
The occasional rocky crag offers some respite from the blizzarding gale
and a few small boulders seem to have come to rest among the half-dead
vegetation.

[36mThe Frigid Plains of Dust[0;37m
    The bitter cold winds blow across the Plains of Dust, cast from the
mighty Icewall that lies to the south. The wind howls as it carries with it
a light powdering of snow which settles on the ground briefly before
melting. The landscape is frozen in time and as unyielding as the compact
earth beneath your feet. Weathered shrubs have found a way to cling to
life, growing mere inches as the years drag on, but they only seem to
confirm the sparsity of the land. The chilling winds rise and fall with
immeasurable precision, yet they never seem to cease.

[36mAt the Edge of Icewall[0;37m
    Sand and snow intermingle in the knifing breeze which blow from the
south. In the distance the massive partition of the Icewall Glacier forms
an impassable barrier, while the north seems to be almost unbroken save the
occasionally half-formed cliff face or pile of bereft boulders. The
powdered scintilla in the air rest briefly on the ground before being
forced aloft again by the sempiternal winds, providing little topsoil to
nurture the scattered brush which clings tenuously to life.

[36mThe Frigid Plains of Dust[0;37m
    A thin layer of snow lies atop the densely scattered rocks which
comprise the bedrock in the plains. The sand with which they are contained
lie motionless, as if huddled together for warmth as the icy wind assails
the terrain. To the south lie the lands of Icereach, a region even more
unforgiving than the Plains of Dust, yet even more majestic. The sunlight
glints and sparkles as it is reflected from the massive glaciers, making it
seem as though there are two suns.

[36mAt the Edge of Icewall[0;37m
    The Icewall Glacier forms a massive shelf of scintillating light along
the distant southern border of the Plains of Dust. Freezing winds blow off
the frigid wall, blasting across the countryside unbounded by building or
tree. A few plants have grown, despite the inhospitable soil and the
knifelike arctic blasts. The occasionally rocky crag offers some respite
from the blizzarding gale, and a few small boulders seem to have come to
rest among the half-dead vegetation.

[36mAt the Edge of Icewall[0;37m

Icewall Glacier glowers with insidious intent, while granite boulders lay
in strangely scattered gaggles between the ever-moving snowdrifts. A few
tough stalks of the most fortitudinous plants creep out from between stone
and ice, a reminder that life always finds a way.

[36mAt the Edge of Icewall[0;37m

the horizon like the frozen blade of a forgotten sword. The wastrel sands
of the Plains of Dust whirl uselessly in the unceasing breezes, creating a
faint interplay of opposing whirlwinds. Almost no life dares to breach the
lifeless soil of these accursed plains, but a faint powder of snow does
intermingle with the resilient brush that has dared to challenge the harsh
environment.

endless cold plains famous from the cataclysm.

[36mIcia Rapids[0;37m

contained to the edges of the river, leaving a safe route through the
center of the river. The river continues to flow to the north, and a bank
to the south seems to offer egress from the river.

[36mIcia River[0;37m
    You float along in the frigid waters of the Icia River, allowing the
current to carry you north. The water seems to pick up speed here as the
river narrows before entering the rapids to the north. Large rocks churn
the water to a froth there, and it may be dangerous to continue in that
direction. The bank to the east looks easy enough to climb , or you can
fight the current back south.

small beads of sap dotting the fresh wood of the breaks.  Snow ladens

piles of snow on those so foolish as to bump them.

[36mDeep in the Frigid Waters[0;37m
    Large chunks of frozen water float through the surrounding area, acting
as a constant reminder of the icy temperature of this body of water. There
are very few life forms around other than a few tiny fish, and the water is
eerily still. Faint rays of light filter through the dark waters from
above, but nowhere near enough to illuminate the surroundings. The water is
so cold that it is almost painful, and it is difficult to understand how
anything could survive down here for an extended period.

[36mA Solitary Building[0;37m
    Inside, this dwelling is quite cozy.  Most of the cracks and holes have
been patched or filled with ordure to seal them.  In one corner, a stone
hearth lies stacked with wood, ready to be fed into the small firepit.
A soot blackened hole in the roof has been cunningly sheltered to allow the
smoke to escape while keeping the snow out.  A small pile of pelts is heaped
atop a large rug made from the skin of a snow leopard.  An altar, nearly
hidden behind a fur hung from the ceiling, is the only indication that this
is the abode of the village holy-man.

[36mBeside a Frozen Stream[0;37m
    Small, stunted trees grown along the frozen stream.  Some of the
branches of the trees have broken from the chill, and hang uselessly,
small beads of sap dotting the fresh wood of the breaks.  Snow ladens
the branches, and makes them hang low the the ground, as well as dumping

[36mAt the Huge Oak[0;37m
    You stand at the base of a massive oak tree, easily the largest you
have seen in these woods. Its trunk is so wide that two people could not
wrap their arms around it, and it towers above the other trees around it.
The ground surrounding the base is covered with a soft grass free of weeds
and dead leaves, making it look as though the tree has been raised, instead
of just growing here.

[36mThe Inn of the Last Home[0;37m
    The Inn of the Last Home is a cozy tavern. The smells of rich food and
the sounds of merry music overflow your senses. A huge fireplace dominates
one wall and a warm glow emanates from its flames. Small tables fill the
room. A stairway leads up, further into the tree, while another stairway
leads down to the forest below.

[36mA Small Side Street[0;37m
    You stand before the largest vallenwood you have ever seen. It towers
up above the rest of the huge vallenwoods and appears to touch the clouds
above. When you look up into the vallenwood, you see an extravagantly
decorated tavern that has been built in and among the limbs of the tree.
The clearing stretches on towards the north and you see Northern Avenue to
the east. A spiral stairway winds down from the tavern above, reaching the
ground a short distance away. A small sign is posted next to the stairway.
